user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_has_token_caseless_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (const char *str,
                             const char *const token,
                             size_t token_len)
{
  if (0 == token_len)
    return false;

  while (0 != *str)
  {
    size_t i;
    /* Skip all whitespaces and empty tokens. */
    while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str || ',' == *str)
      str++;

    /* Check for token match. */
    i = 0;
    while (1)
    {
      const char sc = *(str++);
      const char tc = token[i++];

      if (0 == sc)
        return false;
      if (! charsequalcaseless (sc, tc))
        break;
      if (i >= token_len)
      {
        /* Check whether substring match token fully or
         * has additional unmatched chars at tail. */
        while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str)
          str++;
        /* End of (sub)string? */
        if ((0 == *str) || (',' == *str) )
          return true;
        /* Unmatched chars at end of substring. */
        break;
      }
    }
    /* Find next substring. */
    while (0 != *str && ',' != *str)
      str++;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. The code uses only standard C constructs: function definition, pointer and const qualifiers, size_t, character literals, integer constants, while/if control flow, and calls to other functions (e.g. charsequalcaseless). The use of bool is a standard C99/_Bool feature (via stdbool.h) rather than a compiler extension. There are no occurrences of known compiler-extension tokens such as __attribute__, __asm, __extension__, __builtin_*, typeof, register storage-class misuse, GCC statement-expressions, inline assembler, or other vendor-specific keywords. The identifier naming (trailing underscore) and idioms like while(1) are not language extensions. Because no extension-specific syntax is present in the shown code, there are no fragments to report for Rule 1.2.
